comments.commentBody: Considering Congress has about a 10% approval rating it seems 90% of Americans hold Congress in contempt.

@Richard Luettgen - yes, our political system has been broken. Not completely, but severely damaged by a rise in partisan strife. Perhaps Clinton would have been "more of the same," but Trump? Trump is more than a reset. It's clearing the table and seeding it with corruption of the highest order. That's more than a step backward. Are you on board with eliminating the Dept. of Education? You don't give a damned about the need for a greater educated population who can fill the many intellectual jobs that are open and salivated over by immigrants? You don't give a damn about the EPA, and that businesses should be allowed to pollute to their hearts content, because you and others believe the Earth is one massive sponge and can take all of our refuse without disturbing the ecology and ecosystems we depend upon? And Trump's fruitless promise to revive coal, the dirtiest form of fossil fuel resources, which will only compound pollution?
If you are on board with all that, you're part of the problem. Insidiously so. And it so deeply sickens the rest of us who have far greater sense.

I agree with the views you express in this piece, except I don't think calling Russia our "enemy" is helpful. You could say the Russian government is corrupt, undemocratic, dangerous, and even murderous, but that doesn't necessarily mean they are our "enemy". Perhaps "nemesis" would be more apt? Furthermore, it's not the entire country of Russia that should be derided. Let's not all be automatons and mindless get on this "demonize Russia" train. I don't like the Russian government at all. But I think we do more damage than good if we keep beating this enemy drum.

"“We are not an ethno-state, with identity rooted in shared blood. The option of a White Man’s Republic ended at Appomattox."

Yes.

What wall? What deportations, other than harassing a few extra people? What economic plan? What infrastructure plan? The only thing that keeps him from the laughable dregs is a burgeoning stock market, which he has had almost nothing to do with. It was primed to go high at the advent of reckless libertarian promises. If he doesn't deliver on his tax cuts to the rich, Wall Street will find ways to get rid of him.

Mr. Cohen could perhaps have spelled the reference to "volk" with capital V, so that every reader is able to immediately associate his warnings  to the lessons to be drawn from XXth century German history.

Not "better," but more compassionate, hold the true tenets of
Christianity to be our brothers' keepers, respect our blessed land and water
for all citizens, not Corporations.
In other words, I am proud of my ignorance, and thank god, this social media access gives me the opportunity to express myself.

Dear Amigo: It's customary to shake hands at a congressional talk - even a
dangerous President like Trump who has recklessly come to power in the most
questionable way. We shall see who and what the score is after the truth, the
real truth not the alt-truth is exposed to all Americans. Liberals have no zeros sir -
we are people who support the constitution and the long held values in this country. Shame on you for not being aware of the farce this Trump presidency
has revealed of itself. Put your thinking cap on and get your grey cells working.

Trump never hid his contempt for all the aspects -- foreign policy establishment, Constitution, etc. -- Cohen mentions.  So what does that say about the people who elected him with their eyes wide shut?
It's absolutely clear that Trump must be removed.  Folks, let's try to do it legally - which would not only help preserve our nation but also would provide the most humiliation.

"Trump is not my "ideological leader": he is a necessary tool summoned by history to labor at making productive again what has become a dysfunctional politics."

45 is a "tool" alright, but not the productive type you mean. Sometimes on of those old bromides really does apply. In this case it's "You can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear."
We do accept the result of the election, Marcus Aurelius.  And that's why we're in a constant state of fear for our lives.

Thank you Mr. Cohen.  You are right.   The Foreign Service AKA diplomatic service (in which I spent my career) is rudderless and wondering whether what so many of us sought to build by way of international alliances supporting American power and  a general peace is about to collapse    The few older friends I still have left in the active service are leaving because they cannot tolerate (or be tolerated) in the "age of Trump."   So like it or not, "the torch has been passed to a new generation"  (does anyone recall that phrase or whence it came?).  I can only hope that the new order lasts only 4 years--not 1000--and we wake up in 2020 to sanity and the realistic (and hard) agenda ahead.

Mr. Cohen:

Thanks for another well presented set of thoughts on where we stand today.

You do many things very well.

Today's reminder of the important values of this American experiment through the lens of oaths, summarized elsewhere as the covenants and creeds of this social and political community, is a call for all of us to renew and state anew our civic commitment.

"America’s long-held opposition to spheres of influence." What world does Cohen live in? What is Latin America if not a US sphere of influence? In fact, every region of the world is viewed as a sphere of influence for US power. That's how the Cold War was fought. That's why we went into VietNam and supported dictators around the world, from the Shah of Iran to Marcos, to Pinochet and Mobutu.  Power, not democracy, has always been the number one concern of US foreign policy. Stop with the hypocrisy.
Yes so much for great leadership. Someone said that I am a great leader and Inwill surround myself with great people who will lead and drain the swamp. Well we're still waiting?

Why would Trump be at war with the press? And why do so many people support his war? Perhaps it is because we live in a country that is 40% R, 40% D, and 20% I, yet the press (media) is 90% D. This horrible mismatch between the media and its customers leads to all kinds of resentment, distrust and even hatred towards the media. This phenomena would mainly go away if we had an honest and, on the whole, a non-biased media.
The author of this post should cite his stats.  The 90% of journalists remark is particularly absurd.  False facts, again.  Sad.

Apparently the Republican party has called a time out on truth.
As long as they are in power, truth is just a little problem that can be ignored.
I keep waiting for the party to put country first.
I'm not holding my breath.

He should have released it! It may have made just the difference in countering James Comey.

He should release it now. Any defense funds could be crowd-sourced, although I'm sure he has more than enough of his own money to pay for and mount a skilled defense.

Oh, please. I realize I am "feeding the trolls" by responding, so I'll keep this short. It was clear Pelosi meant she had never had a 1:1, secretly arranged "meeting" (the way Sessions had, and then lied about it under oath); posting a picture where she sat with Russian officials years ago, with numerous other US and foreign diplomats present, on documented and official (and open) business, which she never lied about under oath, is something altogether different. False equivalency and goal post moving is the lowest form of "debate" tactics, and won't work with people far from Twitter or other internet corners of pro-Trump propaganda.
Maybe when Social Security and Medicare are privatized and grabbed by the invisible hand of the market, the 65 million voters may change their views.
Left out:  America and China agree on American troop withdrawal from South Korea, in return China removes the Kim family from power and installs a non-nuke government.
Your comment hits the nail on the head, and in just one sentence.
This is the only attractive suggestion I've read so far.  But would the Chinese authorities play along?  Would the South Koreans?

That is a good general outline.

We could go further to offer demilitarization of Korea, and de-escalation around China. I am thinking of the Washington Naval Limitation Treaty work of 1921, that included an end to fortifications across a vast area, to keep the sides apart.

Yes, vouchers and charters divert money from the traditional public schools. Yes, this causes the poorest kids to suffer.
Yes, when I sent my children to private high school (although I still paid about $10K in property/school taxes), Dallas ISD lost my child's allotment of money.

But even if Christians band together to flood the public schools with their presence, thus returning millions of dollars to a district's coffers, I'm here to tell you that it won't matter. Dozens of my neighbors and I tried.

The creaking Titanic of regulations, bureaucrats, testing, more testing, directives to ignore discipline problems, constant teacher turnover due to regulations/bureaucrats/constant testing/discipline issues, etc will cause all of those kids to suffer, too. And the money? It will just be handed out to a fleet of adults who never interact with a child; it certainly won't be spent on Sp Ed services, reading interventionists, or school psychologists.

Almost all URBAN districts need to be dismantled. They are the DMVs of education; they are the Detroits of education. There is no saving them. They're too big, too entrenched, and completely unresponsive.

I agree. I don't think the main issue is that Russians influenced our elections. It's that Russians have and will influence our government now that this Putin puppet is in office. For the life of me, I can't imagine how Fox news has convinced such a large swath of what used to be stolid anti-Communist Republicans, who still hate the idea of opening up Cuba, that everything is just hunky dory in this administration's dealings with Russia. How can they be such foolish apologists for such a serious enemy? For heaven's sake, Putin and Trump have done everything but French kiss on the White House steps.
